description: Unknown origin. Possibly cognate with Old Norse þveit (“cut, slit, forest clearing”), and if so a doublet of thwaite. May however simply be onomatopoeic or sound-symbolic.

entries.meaning: (offensive, vulgar, slang, chiefly UK, Ireland, Australia, New Zealand) A contemptible and stupid person, idiot.
examples: At 4pm, the phone went. It was The Sun: 'We hear your daughter's been expelled for cheating at her school exams...'She'd made a remark to a friend at the end of the German exam and had been pulled up for talking.As they left the exam room, she muttered that the teacher was a 'twat'. He heard and flipped—a pretty stupid thing to do, knowing the kids were tired and tense after exams. Instead of dropping it, the teacher complained to the Head and Deb was carpeted.

verbs.description: twat (third-person singular simple present twats, present participle twatting, simple past and past participle twatted)

examples: Arnold Rimmer: What are we gonna do?
Dave Lister: Well, I say let's get out there and twat it!
